abstract.text: An editing session for modifying the photo, video, and audio content of a Live Photo.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A Live Photo is a picture, captured by a supported iOS device, that includes motion and sound from the moments just before and after it was taken. Editing the content of a Live Photo works much like editing other asset types:
In an app using the Photos framework, fetch a
object that represents the Live Photo to edit, and use that object’s
method to retrieve a
object.
In a photo editing extension that runs within the Photos app, your extension’s main view controller (which adopts the
protocol) receives a
object when the user chooses to edit a Live Photo with your extension.
2. Create a Live Photo editing context with the
initializer.
You can create a Live Photo editing context only from
object that represents a Live Photo. Use the
property of the editing input to verify that it has live Photo content.
3. Use the
property to define a block to be used in processing the Live Photo’s visual content. Photos will call this block repeatedly to process each frame of the Live Photo’s video and still photo content.
4. Create a
object to store the results of your edit, then call the
to process the Live Photo and save it to your editing output object. This method applies your
to each frame.
You can also use the
method to process a preview-quality version of the Live Photo to display in your app’s UI during editing.
To allow a user to continue working with the edit later (for example, to adjust the parameters of a filter), create a
object describing your changes, and store it in the
property of your editing output.
In an app using the Photos framework, use a photo library change block to commit the edit. (For details, see
.) In the block, create a
object and set its
property to the editing output that you created.
In a photo editing extension, provide the
object that you created in your main view controller’s
method.
When you use either of the methods listed in Processing an Editing Context’s Live Photo, Photos calls your
block repeatedly to process each frame of the Live Photo’s video and still photo content. In that block, a
object provides the Live Photo’s existing content as a
object. You use Core Image to modify the image, then provide the result of your edits by returning a
object representing the result of processing the input image.
Core Image provides several ways to process the Live Photo’s visual content. You can use the built-in filters listed in
or create
subclasses using custom graphics kernel code. Or, to use other image processing technologies, you can directly access and modify image content in pixel buffers, Metal textures, or
objects with a custom
subclass.

abstract.text: An image processor that produces an image by manipulating one or more input images or by generating new image data.
A representation of an image to be processed or produced by Core Image filters.
The abstract class you extend to create custom image processors that can integrate with Core Image workflows.
Make a request to modify and save a photo or video asset.
Keys indicating the status of an asset content editing request, used in the completion handler of the
method.
Work with image and video assets that the Photos app manages, including those from iCloud Photos and Live Photos.
A description of the edits made to an asset’s photo, video, or Live Photo content, which allows your app to reconstruct or revert the effects of prior editing sessions.
A representation of an image, video, or Live Photo in the Photos library.
Returns whether the asset supports the specified editing operation.
Cancels a request for editing the asset’s content.
Requests asset information for beginning a content editing session.
A request to create, delete, change metadata for, or edit the content of a Photos asset, for use in a photo library change block.
The output of an asset content editing session.
Values identifying possible actions an asset can support, used by the
method.
A container that provides information about and access to the image, video, or Live Photo content of an asset to be edited.
The unedited Live Photo content of the editing input.
An identifier for an asset content editing session.
A set of options affecting the delivery of image or video data when you request to edit the content of a Photos asset.
A container to which you provide the results of editing the photo, video, or Live Photo content of a Photos asset.
An object describing the changes made to the asset.
An editing session for modifying the photo, video, and audio content of a Live Photo.
The audio gain to apply to the processed Live Photo.
Aborts any Live Photo processing in progress.
The duration, in seconds, of the Live Photo.
A block to be called by Photos for processing each frame of the Live Photo’s visual content.
The unedited still photo content of the Live Photo.
Creates a Live Photo editing context for the specified editing input.
The image orientation of the Live Photo.
The offset, in seconds, from the beginning of the Live Photo’s duration to the time corresponding to its still photo.
Processes a Live Photo with your edits for viewing.
Processes and saves a full-quality Live Photo as the output of your editing session.
Error codes for Live Photo editing errors.
The domain value for error objects produced by a Live Photo editing context.
Keys for the
dictionary used with the methods listed in Processing an Editing Context’s Live Photo.
A container that provides image content for a single frame of a Live Photo in an editing context.
The signature for a block Photos calls to process Live Photo frames.
An object that manages access and changes to the user’s photo library.
A protocol your custom view controller class implements to provide a user interface for your Photos extension.
Asks your extension for edited asset data to finish the editing session.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
